all_paragraphs: “You shall know a word by the company it keeps” — John Firth
Natural Language Processing (NLP) helps computers understand texts and by simulating how human understands texts.

Due to the data growth in recent years, NLP has grown rapidly. Especially with the rise of Twitter, Facebook, and Google to process unstructured data in search engines or personal AI assistants. More and more application of NLP has gained immense popularity.
Consider Google Search of cat images. What cats do you mean?
There are so many cats. You have mutant cats in “cats” theatric shows. You have cartoon cats. Which one are you talking about?
The adjacent word such as “Cute” and “Show” further explains what I want. This is the context to evaluate NLP performance.
Consider Google Home Mini which you can just buy using $50. Does it understand query context?
Imagine your little daughter asks Google Home Mini on her assignment project “Ok Google, Define twinkle-twinkle little star”.
Should not Google Home smart enough to know that it is the title of a song?
Imagine you wanted to predict Donald Trump’s triumph over Hillary Clinton during the last presidential elections.
Could you predict it from the general sentiments on Twitter? How and what were the points of satisfaction of each presidential candidate?
Imagine your Master/Bachelor Class Forums: It is very hard to extract what’s important from all of those informations.
Could you build a model that potentially extract all of the key topics and filter the posts based on that?
NLP is getting more and more ubiquitous and important to study. The potential is huge and is used in every part of the world now.
NLP’s biggest enemy is ambiguity, and NLP’s biggest friend is context — Vincent Tatan
“Why r u so gloomy? Have fun lah!
For us, it seems that the meaning of the words are very clear. “r u” represents “are you” and “what’s up” is a common American informal greeting.

However, there are ambiguities in these sentences. “What’s up” literal answer should be “The sun is up” not “I am good, thank you”. There are hidden contexts that make it hard for us to explain the computer what these sentences exactly mean.
Most of the time, we assume the listener will fill in lots of gaps based on our knowledge of the world and shared context.
What do we already know about each other?
Interestingly, we don’t know how meaning arises from words in our brains. But it all feels very easy to us.
This is why that we need Machine Learning and NLP techniques for the computer to identify these rules and contexts from corpuses of text.
In this lesson we are going to use this Colab to follow through the tutorial. Feel free to open this and run directly. This colab shows a simple application of NLP.
Imagine you ask your daughters about what they love to eat. One of the kids answered “I love ice cream!” Can you guess whether they are smiling excitedly or frowning?
Can you do that if I just showed you the word “I <insert word here> Ice cream”? How do you know if this kid is frowning or not?
To answer this sentimental analysis question, let us break down NLP to these basic principles:
Tokenization decomposes texts into tokens and indexes which are understandable by computers.

We will talk about how to understand words by tokenizing them. Consider the word FRIED. We can represent these alphabets with ASCII numbers. But FIRED also has the same letters but different word due to the orders.
Ok, then let’s use the words instead. In the text “I love my dog” we can encode it per word → 1[I], 2[love], 3[my], 4[dog]. We will take a look at the code to achieve the tokenization
The Tokenizer API already removed all of the exclamation mark and punctuations around which are handy to get your word tokens quickly.

First we need to tokenize our APIs from Keras. Then we can create the sentences. Num_words parameter here meaning the number of words to keep. In this case, we will keep 100 most frequent words that appear in the corpuses.
How about if the tokenizer finds words that do not exist in the word_index? Then we need to specify Out of Vocabulary (OOV) tokens and which identifies the word as index 1.
Congrats! You just indexed these tokens for training!
Sequencing represents sentences from sequence of words and their respective indexes. We use tokenizer.texts_to_sequence to translate the corpuses into tokens in sequences.

Sequencing is important because the order of the words matter. “I love fish” and “fish love I “ has different semantic meaning and grammatical error. The order of the sentence determines which token gets to be the object or subject of the meaning.

This sequences the tokens and padded the remaining token spaces to match the dimension of the longest sequences. These are important to run mathematical operations during embedding/sentimental analysis.
Note that there are several indexes we can extract from here:
Padding allows us to standardize the length of each corpus. This makes it easier to run multiple operations with numpy and prepare it for Neural Network (NN) training.
Embedding projects an input into multi dimensional representation space. For example we can project the following words into polarity sub space.
Let’s plot each word in multi dimension spaces. Then when we want to have the combined meanings. We can combine these vectors together and generate the unified vectors.

For example good is considered positive sentiment and bad is considered negative sentiment. But if you use good … and bad … in the same sentence (e.g: I think your essay is good, but your handwriting is bad), then the sentiment is neutral.
By experimenting with Tensorflow and Keras, we could train a Neural Network with embedding as our inputs. With this colab notebook, you could experiment doing Kaggle problem and run the codes.
There are more applications of such to NLP. And I hope that this simple tutorial can whet your appetite to explore on how you can process words and languages.
Grammar and Vocabularies are complex. We need more techniques to derive our features and tokenize better.
